document.text: In  itional to the previously an- ounced dates an Internal Revenue representative will be in Appomattax on January 27. This makes it possible for anyone desiring help on their income tax forms to get aid from the office of Commissioner of Revenue, J. H. OBrien, on the dates of January 26, and 27, and February 4 and 5. The hours are from 9 a. m. to 430 p. m. It is pointed out that anyone de siring aid should bring complete in formation as to their income and deductions and also the original copy of their information slip, Form W-2 furnished by each place they have received wages or salary during the year 1952.

document.text: Tuesday, Nov. 8, is General Election day in Virginia, and a last minute effort is being made to get out a sizeable vote for Appomattox County. There are approximately 2,500 eligible voter in the county, but thus far there has been a min imum of interest, and the size of the actual vote is uncertain. To be elected are unopposed candi dates for the State Senate and the House of Delegates, and a slate of unopposed nominees for county of fices. Polling places will open at 6 A. M. and close at 6 P. M. There are ten precincts in the county. The candidates, all Democrats, are as follows For the State Senate, Chas. T. Moses. For the House of Delegates John B. Boatwright. For Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt, Jr. For County Treasurer John G. Plunkett. For Commissioner of the Revenue J. H. OBrien. For Sheriff David T. Robertson. For Supervisor in Southside Dis trict F. L. Murphy. For Supervisor in the Stonewall District Otho W. Martin, Jr. For Supervisor in the Colver Hill District Richard Webb. For Justice of the Peace, South- side District Cree to be elected T. W. Moses, Mrs. Lucille S. Con ner and E. T Guill. The officials to be elected Tues day will take office in January. In appealing for a good turn-out of voters next Tuesday, the quality of the candidates listed and the im portance of the eounty maintaining a record for a large vote, were cited as reasons for everyone making an effort to cast their ballots.

document.text: The general election in Appomat tox county Tuesday was like the present war in E u ro p e.... it was All quiet on the front! With no contests, and only one candidate for county offices, -only 613 voters wont to the polls! There were over 1,800 eltg ble Viters. The total vote by precincts was as follows Court Home, 194 Cheatwood, 8 Chap, 22 Rocks, 25 Pamplin, 04 Walkers Church, 35 Clover Hill, 81 Agee, 47 Oakville, 50 Stonewall, 87. document.text: Nearly 800 ballots were cast in Appomattox Countys ten precincts in Tuesdays General Election, as all Democratic nominees were elect ed without opposition. The vote wa3 considered a fairly good showing in the light of lack of opposing candi dates and was slightly ahead of the total vote in last years general elec tion. J. H. OBrien, commissioner of the revenue, topped the voting with a total of 73 b ballots, closely follow ed by J. Garland Plunkett with 736 for county treasurer. The big court house,precinct here- was just short of 300 votes cast. State Senator Chas. T. Moses was re-elected to another four-year term, receiving 718 ballots in the county. Delegate John B. Boatwright receiv ed 665. Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt Jr. received 692 votes, sheriff David T. Robertson 693,and the 3 unopposed candidates for supervisor, F. L. Murphy, Otho Matrin Jr. and R. M. Webb received 320, 213, and 186 votes respectively. Interest over the state centered in a few contests for the State Senate and House of Delegates, where Re publican or Independent carididates sought to win over Democrats. In most cases the Democrats won, al though Ted Dalton was returned to the State Senate and gained pres tige for another possible bid for the Governorship.

OBrien, Commissioner of the Revenue for Appomattox Coun ty, has announced that a represen tative from the office of Collector of Internal Revenue in Lynchburg will be in Mr. OBriens office here on Monday, January 24. The pur pose of this visit will he to assist and advise farmers and others in the pre paration and filing of income tax returns. It is urged that all who de sire such assistance avail them selves of this opportunity. Mr. Leo Wooldridge is in charge of the Lynchburg office.

document.text: Appomattox voters were given another contest today, as J. Alex Bingham announced as a candidate for county sheriff. He will oppose the incumbent, David T. Robertson, in the Democratic Primary Election of July 12. Contests have already been an nounced for county treasurer, com missioner of the revenue, and super visor in the Stonewall District. Mr. Bingham is a retired Lieute nant, Virginia State Police. He be gan police work in 1922 as an in spector. He was promoted to lieute nant in 1930 and assigned to the Central Virginia territory. In 1942 he became a Special Investigator of the Virginia Department of State Police. It had been reported here for sev eral weeks that Mr. Bingham plan ned on seeking the office of sheriff, but he made formal announcement to the Times-Virginian this week. His opponent, Mr. Robertson, was appointed by the court to serve out the term of the late H. W. McKin ney, and then four years ago won election for a full term. Both of these contestants are popular and experienced police offi cers. Abbitt Announces Commonwealth Attorney George F. Abbitt, Jr. informed the Times- Virginian this week that he would be a candidate for re-election. It is considered certain that he will not have opposition. Candidates for commissioner of revenue are the incumbent, J, H. OBrien, and H. H. Caldwell, Jr. Candidates for county treasurer are deputy treasurer J. Garland Plunkett, and Thomas Terrill Mar tin, local businessman. Contestants for supervisor in the Stonewall District are H. H. Scruggs and O. W. Martin, Jr. NOTICE . .  c  w All children who will begin school at Oakville, Vera and Spout Spring schools this fall, and have not bad their examination, please come to the Appomattox Health Center on Thursday, April 7, 1955, between 900 A. M. and 230 P. M. All other children who have not had their preschool examination please also come on this day, as this is the last day for these exami nations. ,

document.text: Supervisors a n d county of ficials of Appomattox county met at the court house Tues-  day night of this week and agreed to a slashing of the county tax rate and salaries.j The tax-rate will be cut t 1.50 and salaries will be - duced 10 per cent, it fit. agreed. The present i levies run from 1.80 to 1.95. The reduction is expected to cause a bolstering of confidence locally and will be warmly wel comed by tax payers. No con certed demand for a reduction had been made by citizens, but the supervisors and county of f a l s felt that the cut was in .ine with steps already taken by several other counties. The supervisors also felt it best to act in advance of widespread dissatisfaction that might be forthcoming if theratewere not . educed and wisely averted any m a s s meetings of tax payers such as a number of other coun ies have experienced. Th i s act is expected to renew confi dence in the administration of county affairs, and cooperation -vill now be sought in an effort -o avoid drastic cut in upkeep jf roads and the conduct of the jchools. The- statement signed by county supervisors, follows To T h e Taxpayers of Appo mattox Count Realizing the financial con dition of the farmers and citi zens of our county, brought about by the drought of last year, a n d the unprecedented depression whichwe are pass ing, and small demand and low prices for all farm products, and while all of us now receive the lowest salary and compen sation allowed by state laws, but desiring to help relieve the tax burden of o u r people to some extent, hereby express cur willingness and voluntarily agree to accept a ten per cent cut in salary or compensation for the year beginning January 1st, 1932, and pledge ourselves to do everything possible to practice economy in the admin istration of the county affairs, so that the county, school and road levy m a y be reduced to the lowest possible figure. The above ten per cent does not ap ply to the County Treasurer or the Commissioner of the Rev enue, as the reduction in levy automatically reduces their compensation more than ten per cent. C. W. Smith, Clerk R. L. Burke, County Treasurer Jo el W. Flood, Commonwealth Attorney H. W. McKinney, Sheriff J. H. OBrien, Comr. of Revenue J. A. Burke, Supt, of Schools F. A. OBrien, Supervisor Don Moses, Super visor T. E. Owen, Supervisor E. LeRoy Smith, Chairman School Board ,T. J. Ligon, Member School Board j  o! Davidson, Member School Board. ,, 111 viw of the, foregoing, we iu undersififned members of th e Board of Supervisors, whose duty it is to make up the bud get and fix the levy bf the coun ty, desire to state that we wish to do everything we can to low- er the tax rate to t h e lowest possible figure, consistent with sound financing and safeguard ing the institutions of our coun ty. We are sure we can make a substantial reduction in the levy for th e next fiscal year, and agree to make the total levy 1.50 on the 100.00 for all purposes, thus reducing the taxes of the people approxi mately 12,450.00. We real ize this means a substantial cut in county affairs, road building, and length of school term. This includes a reduction in the sal aries and wages of everyone employed by the county, but we feel that an emergency exists , Continued on Page 4

In fact, the wenther seems to brew at the higher levels, and the observations, obtained by small bal loons and kites, often give Informa tion unobtainable nt the level of the earths surface. 43 Balloon Stations Send Data. While no doubt man j have de cided views a to whom they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr, Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight hangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in jected in which Mr. Gannaway ias declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. Terrell other than he is for the administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and su far, that is about the main is sue involved between the two candidates for that office. document.text: Two county incumbents face newly announced opposition this week with the announcement by David M. Wood, Rtr 3,.Appomat tox, on Monday, that he has fil ed to run for county supervisor In the Clover Hill District. In cumbent Clover Hill supervisor, Richard M. Webb, had previous ly made public that he will seek re-election. Thomas E Tommie OBrien announced on Saturday h is candidacy for the post of Com missioner of Revenue, a job hte father. James Dick OBrien, held for over 35 years. Stonewall Supervisor O. W. Martin, Jr., incumbent county supervisor for the Stone wall District, filed Friday with Democratic chairman, Watkins M. Abbitt, to run for re-election to the post he has held for the past two terms. As candidate for commissioner of revenue, Tommie OBrien will be opposed by John Curtis Cald well who defeated his father in the 1959 election. Caldwell is co-owner of th e Ooswell Drive-In Theatre. He a graduate of Appomattox High School, attended the College of William and Mary. He Is mar ried and has two sonsJohn C. Jr., an electrical engineer in Lynchburg, and William, who is a student at the University of Richmond. OBrien, a graduate of Appo mattox High School and fonder football player at VPI, teaches business at E. C. Glass High 8cbool. He is line coach for the football team and assistant bas ketball coach. OBrien is married to the for mer Joanne C. Price, of Panip- lin, and has three children, Kathy. 5, Pam 3, and Kevin 18 months. David Wood, candidate for the Clover Hill supervisors position native of Carbon Hill,  Where he finished high He and his wife, moved pomattox Comity 15 years ago. They have three children, David M. Wood, Jr., Mrs. Raymond Disley, of Cumberland, Ky., and Mrs. Ted Layne, of Rt 4, Ap pomattox. Richard Webb, present super visor from the Clover HUl Dis trict, was elected In 1955 also, and reelected In 1969. Hte won his first term when tocumbeht. Frank Allen OBrien did not of-, fer for reelectlon.. He has had no opposition in either race. J Webb, a farmer and dairy man, is a graduate of Vera High School and is a member of the Appomattox Welfare Board and clerk of Hollywood B a p t i s t Church. He is married to the former Betty Morris, and Has one daughter, Mrs. David Re pass, of Appomattox. Former Councilman H. G. Johnson, former town councilman appointed when A. H. Gregory died In 1926, served three consecutive terms until he resigned In 1939 when trans ferred to Lynchburg as a plant superintendent for Standard OIL He said he is entering the race for the good of the town and not for personal reasons.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: A record 2,603 votes wire cast in Appomattox County Tuesday, as voters of the county chose a Dem ocratic nominee for County Treas- arer Sheriff, and Cimmissioner of the Revenue, and Stonewall District chose a Supervisor.. According to Times - Virginian files, this was the largest vote ever cast in the county. It compared with 2,133 in February, 1948 in a social congressional election, and 1,989 in the 1952 presidential election. James H. OBrien lead the ticket in the county, defeating H. H. Cald well, Jr. for Commissioner of the Revenue, 1,722 t 847. OBrien car ried every precinct but Chap. David T. Robertson won over J. Alex Bingham for Sheriff, by a vote of 1,466 to 1,114. Bingham carried Rocks and Agee precincts. J. Garland Plunkett, incumbent deputy Treasurer defeated Thomas Terrell Martin for the nominatiin for Treasurer, in the countys clos est race. The unofficial tabulation gave Plunkett a 200 vote margin in a spirited race. Plunkett piled up a lead at the Court House and the Old Court House precincts. Martin carried Cheatwood, Chap, Walkers Church, Agee, Oakville and Stone wall precints, his biggest margin be ing at Oakville. There was a record 962 vote at the Court House precinct, and sev eral hundred citizens gathered to wait until nearly 11 P. M. for the cimpletion of the ballot count.  In the Stonewall District, . Otha W. Martin, Jr. handily defeated two opponents for Supervisor. He re ceived 396 votes, to 234 for John P. Alvis, Jr., incumbent, and HuT bert B. Scruggs received 92. Martin swept the Oakville and Agee precincts and Alvis carried the Stonewall precinct.
